Award.AwardTitle: Analytical and Computational Studies of Direct and Inverse Boundary Value Problems for PDEs
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project has two major goals. The first goal is to uncover specific information about the response of various physical systems (described by boundary value problems for partial differential equations) to the presence of inhomogeneities (defects), the spacing of these inhomogeneities, or parametric changes in the boundary conditions. Emphasis is placed on developing very precise asymptotic formulas and a priori estimates that may help to assess the accuracy of these formulas. The work largely (but not exclusively) focuses on steady state and time harmonic situations, considering scalar equations as well as systems (in particular Maxwell's equations). Significant effort will be invested in accurate characterization of the response for a wide range of frequencies. The second goal is to demonstrate how to use such structural knowledge about the nature of the response, in combination with measured data (say, from an accessible part of boundary, or from the "far field") to effectively infer information about the parameters of the system (e.g., the location and the character of the inhomogeneities). Special attention will be given to methods that effectively use a wide range of frequencies to improve reconstructions.





This project investigates fundamental mathematical problems that underlie nondestructive inspection of hidden aspects of objects. Three particular imaging applications concern ground penetrating radar (e.g., for anti-personnel mine detection) eddy current imaging (e.g.. for corrosion assessment), and optimal imaging (for biomedical applications). This work will form a basis for the design of detection (and location) algorithms that are more precise (less sensitive to noise) and much faster than those currently in use. The project will develop software of use to practitioners that will be made publicly available. The work may lead to the development of a theoretical framework that will be useful in many other contexts as well.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electromagnetic cloaking is the ability to render objects undetectable to probing by electromagnetic waves. To be more precise to render the far-field electromagnetic  patterns unperturbed by the presence of  the objects. In one extreme situation this would render the objects (and their very presence) invisible to a human observer at a distance. A significant part of the outcomes of this project concerns approximate cloaking using a technique called "cloaking by mapping" (or sometime "transformational optics"). This "passive" form of cloaking may for instance be achieved by use of a material layer (a cloak)  that is the "push-forward" of a uniform medium by a transformation that maps the spherical shell between the ball of radius 2 and that of radius epsilon<<1, onto the spherical shell between the ball of radius 2 and that of radius 1. In this case the ball of radius 1 would contain the objects to (also) be rendered undetectable. Some of the main results of this project are very precise estimates for the degree of invisibility (or cloaking) obtained from such an approximate scheme. These estimates are in terms of powers of epsilon (or in 2d,  exceptionally 1/ log epsilon), and they have been established in a variety of different situations: (1) for the conductivity equation, (2) for the Helmholtz equation, and (3) for the full, scalar wave equation. The parameter epsilon is directly linked to the anisotropy and the degeneracy of the spherical cloak, and therefore these results can be seen as estimating the degree of invisibility that my be achieved with a given degree of anisotropy and degeneracy. For the Helmholtz equation the estimates are explicit in their dependence on frequency, and this is what permits the generalization to the full, scalar wave equation. Related results from the the project concern optimal design of radial cloaks and the implementation certain piewise constant analogues. The invisibility estimates are based on the results of earlier studies by the PI concerning the uniform asymptotics of the electromagnetic fields in the presence of diametrically small inhomogeneities. During this project we have also derived uniform asymptotics for the electromagnetic fields in the presence of thin inhomogeneities -- estimates that may prove useful to estimate "transformation optics" invisibility in different contexts.

The project outcomes include a novel, integral equation based analysis of bounds on the field derivatives (currents or stresses) for composite media with closely spaced inhomogeneities. They also include results about the formation and location of boundary singularities for solutions to a highly non-linear boundary value problem that models corrosion/oxidation.

During the project three graduate students have been involved with the research. One of these students has graduated (and currently works for Numerix, a company that produces sophisticated software for the financial industry) -- of the other two students, one is well underway with his thesis work, the other has just gotten started.

Four postdocs have been involved at various stages of the project, as have other junior visitors. The postdocs currently have tenure track positions (or equivalent) at University of Houston, EPFL, University of Grenoble and INRIA Sophia-Antipolis.  The collaboration with the four postdocs continue.
